Hi,

=C2=A0I put my NEAT-based experimental setup online, here : http://www=
.marmakoide.org/download/research/blackbolt-neat-1.0.zip
The archive is mos=
tly self-contained, you Python to compile the thing. Documentation included=
 in the package. It's a usage of NEAT, not verbatim HyperNEAT : I use input=
 space to compute thickness of beams of a mechanical structure, not the wei=
ght for a neuron network. But the principle is the same, NEAT algorithm and=
 CPPN.=C2=A0Definitely=C2=A0compile on Unix-ish systems, should compile on =
Windows but not tested that. Call mothership if you need support, we're rea=
dy ^^

Cheers,
Alex

________________________________
 De=C2=A0: afcarl2 <a=
fcarl2@...>
=C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Envoy=C3=A9 le : Mard=
i 15 Novembre 2011 8h51
Objet=C2=A0: Re: Re : Re : Re : [neat] Any Prior Ap=
plications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The Output?
 

=C2=A0 

=

Alex,
If an individual maps to a point evaluation of the design space, and=
 the local jacobian of the fitness landscape is such that an added local gr=
adient based sub-optimization task follows a trajectory resulting in an imp=
roved fitness associated w/ an updated individual, would that satisfy the c=
lassification requirements associated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Als=
o, would you consider uploading your updated version of Hyperneat used in y=
our study to the group file repository?
Thanks,
Andy

--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> =C3=82=C2=A0 I'm=
 not 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I might answer=
 a bit off-target ^^
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0 In that paragraph about the taxonomy=
 (end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's not a gradient, as in=
 "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the local geometry of th=
e objective function. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of local f=
eedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it c=
ould be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it w=
ould be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would the=
 local water flux and pressure.
> 
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0Then, does this local i=
nformation feeback turns "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit e=
volved embryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say=
 you decode the genotype as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a f=
inal one. You have many many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as =
a very flexible transformation (many many development steps, each doing sma=
ll changes in all possible ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very ha=
d-hoc transformation step). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" an=
d "implicit evolved embryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of pos=
sibilities rather than a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a =
trully "implicit evolved embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But i=
n practice, allowing a few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility=
 for a genotype, so it's a rethoritical remark.
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Alex
> 
>=
 
> ________________________________
> De=C3=82=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@...=
>
> =C3=83=E2=82=AC=C3=82=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Envoy=C3=83=C2=A9 l=

> Objet=C3=82=C2=A0: Re: Re : Re : [neat] A=
ny Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The Output?
>=
 
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0 
> 
> 
> Alex,
> Thank you for the link! Question: In y=
our opinion, does the added presence of local gradient-based optimization o=
f the design space transition the classification definition from "external =
non-evolved embryogeny" to "implicit evolved embryogeny"? BTW, I am attract=
ed to your more flexible taxonomy, as I have never been fully comfortable w=
ith the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
> Thanks,
> Andy
> 
>=

      <div><br>
<br>
Alex,<br>
If an indivi=
dual maps to a point evaluation of the design space, and the local jacobian=
 of the fitness landscape is such that an added local gradient based sub-op=
timization task follows a trajectory resulting in an improved fitness assoc=
iated w/ an updated individual, would that satisfy the classification requi=
rements associated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you consid=
er uploading your updated version of Hyperneat used in your study to the gr=
oup file repository?<br>
Thanks,<br>
Andy<br>
<br>
--- In <a rel=3D"nofollo=
w" ymailto=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mail=
to:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, Alexandre Devert <m=
armakoide@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hi,<br>
> =C3=82  I'm no=
t 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I might answer a =
bit off-target ^^<br>
> <br>
> =C3=82  In that paragraph about t=
he taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's not a grad=
ient, as in "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the local geo=
metry of the objective function. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind=
 of local feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane=
 wing, it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exch=
anger, it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, i=
t would the local water flux and pressure.<br>
> <br>
> <br>
> =C3=
=82 Then, does this local information feeback turns "external non-evol=
ved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy ter=
ritory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype as a transformatio=
n of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many many ways to do thi=
s, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transformation (many many d=
evelopment steps, each doing small changes in all possible ways) or a very =
inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation step). So between "ext=
ernal non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embryogeny", I believe =
there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than a sharp border betwe=
en the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved embryogeny", it wo=
uld unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a few steps of develop=
ment brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's a rethoritical rem=
ark.<br>
> <br>
> Cheers,<br>
> <br>
> Alex<br>
> <br>
> =
